name: 1890s News
rawContent:
1895

July
Leslie Darwin and Lew Berens, of New Whatcom, brought Mr. and Mrs. O. H. Culver and the Misses Simpson of Fairhaven, over to Point Lawrence Friday night in the fine sloop Mabel, of Whatcom, and returned with them Monday Morning.

Saturday evening last there was a delightful little dinner party at the pleasant home of Miss Aiken and Miss Agnes Aiken, near Point Lawrence, given by them in honor of the birthday of their sister, Mrs. G.N. Culver. Those present were Mr. and Mrs. Culver, Miss Culver, Mr. Alex Chalmers, Mr. Bert Chalmers and Mr. Holt, of Doe Bay, Mr. Jas. Geoghegan of Eastsound, Mr. and Mrs. O.H. Culver and Misses Blanche and Pearl Simpson of Fairhaven.

Fire at Alderbrook: The old Alderbrook farm house, near Doe Bay, Orcas island, belonging to G. N. And O. H. Culver, was entirely destroyed by fire Tuesday night of last week. The new farm house built on the same property is safe. Mr. G. N. Culver and family who occupied the new house are safe.

1896

January
Mr. G. N. Culver of Point Lawrence has taken charge of Miss Mary Jane Aiken, who is seriously sick.

Mrs. G. N. Culver and daughter, Miss Louise, of Point Lawrence, left for her son's home in Fairhaven. She was soon recalled, however, by the serious illness of her sister, Miss Mary Jane Aiken.

Miss Aiken died, causing much grief in the community.

Miss Louise Culver of Point Lawrence, Orcas island, visited her brothers in Fairhaven a day or two during the week.

Wm. Reilly, of Pt. Lawrence, a well known farmer of Orcas Island, was in the town Thursday, returning home Friday.

February
Mr. G. N. Culver, of Pt. Lawrence, Orcas island, was in Friday Harbor during the week.

The friends of Miss Mabel Culver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. N. Culver, of Point Lawrence, were sorry to learn this week that she is very ill.

March
Miss Louise Culver, of Point Lawrence, Orcas island, was in Whatcom Saturday, en route to Olympia to visit her brother, Carroll Culver, who is a page in the legislature.

April
Mrs. G. N. Culver, of Point Lawrence, Orcas Island, is visiting her son, O.H. Culver and family, at New Whatcom.

William and John Viereck have become disgusted with shingle bolt cutting in Whatcom County and quit. William has gone to Seattle to hunt for another job and John is working for G.N. and O.H. Culver at Alderbrook farm, Point Lawrence.

Miss Louise Culver, of Alderbrook farm, Point Lawrence, went to Whatcom the last of the week to make her brother O.H. Culver and family a two or three weeks visit.

A representative of this journal in walking from Doe Bay to Point Lawrence, Orcas Island, last Saturday afternoon was pleased to note the many improvements on the various ranches which he passed and also in the county road.

May
Mr. and Mrs. G. N. Culver, Miss Culver and Mr. Fred Culver, who have been visiting the Bay Cities and relatives, returned home Thursday.

June
Miss Louise Culver, of Alderbrook farm, Point Lawrence, accompanied her brother, Mr. F. N. Culver, and wife to their home in Fairhaven, Sunday, to spend a few days visiting.

Mr. and Mrs. G. N. Culver and Fred N. Culver, of Point Lawrence, spent the Fourth at Whatcom, arriving there Saturday afternoon. They went out to Rose Lake for picnic dinner and with the rest of Whatcom County's population spent the Fourth in Bellingham Bay.

Mrs. F. N. Culver of Fairhaven, has been at Point Lawrence, Orcas Island, for a couple of weeks past visiting relatives.

July
Miss Nellie Willis Dasher, of Puyallup, is visiting her uncle, Mr. G. N. Culver, and family, at Alderbrook farm, Point Lawrence. Miss Dasher met the party Saturday at Fairhaven and returned with them to Point Lawrence. Mr. Culver had not seen his niece for 26 years.

September
The sloop Bertha, with a party of eleven aboard sailed into the harbor Saturday evening and dropped anchor, remaining here until Sunday evening. The party consisted of the following persons, who, while, here were the guests of Mr. and Mrs. F. N. Culver: Mrs. Jas. T. Gander and Mr. A. McLean, of Fairhaven, brother and sister of Mrs. Culver, Miss E. Louise Culver, Point Lawrence, Orcas Island, Miss Nellie Dasher, of Puyallup, and Mr. John G. Viereck Jr., of Point Lawrence. Mr. Viereck, who had charge of the boat and handled the ribbons to the sails, is one of the safest and most trusted sailors on the Sound.

October
Mrs. G. N. Culver, of Point Lawrence, Orcas island, has been in the city for several days past the guest of her son, Mr. F. N. Culver and family.

November
Miss Louise Culver, of Point Lawrence, is visiting her brother O. H. Culver and family in Whatcom this week.

Mrs. G. N. Culver returned to Point Lawrence, Monday, from a week's visit with her sons, O.H. and F.N. Culver, in Whatcom.

December
Mr. G. N. Culver of Point Lawrence has sold his place to a Mr. Garvey and will remove with his family to North Dakota, near Grand Forks, where his father has a large farm upon which he desires his sons assistance.

Roy Reilly, about 18 years old, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Reilly, who formerly kept a restaurant at Sehome Junction, was drowned near Point Lawrence, Orcas Island, in the heavy gale last Wednesday. He was trying to cross from Clark's Island to Orcas in a small boat. His father, who was on Clark's island, saw him disappear, but was powerless to help him.

Mr. D. J. Slattery, of Point Lawrence, Orcas Island, was in town the first of the week on business.

Mrs. Wm. Reilly, of Point Lawrence, Orcas Island, spent Christmas visiting relatives in Whatcom.

1897

January
O. H. Culver of Whatcom was in the Harbor on business connected with The Islander.

March
Mr. G. N. Culver of Point Lawrence, will sail next week for the Carriboo mines in British Columbia.

April
Mr. Fred N. Culver of Fairhaven, the well known marine reporter has accepted the position of local editor on The Islander.

September
Born: A daughter to Mr. and Mrs. O. H. Culver, at New Whatcom, September 11.

Miss Louise Culver, of Point Lawrence, visited her brother and his family at Whatcom this week.

Mr. G. N. Culver of Point Lawrence, Orcas Island, visited the Bay Cities the last of the week.

October
Mrs. F. N. Culver and little daughter are visiting relatives and friends at Point Lawrence, Orcas island.

November
The building built especially for the customs office and resident of the office in charge is being thoroughly repaired and will soon be occupied by the new collector and his family. Mrs. Culver and children are now at the Culver farm, near Point Lawrence.

Mr. G. N. Culver, of Point Lawrence, Orcas island, was in the city on business on Friday and Saturday of last week.

1898

January
Miss Blanche Simpson returned Monday on the Buckeye, after a week's visit with friends at Fairhaven and at Point Lawrence, Orcas island.

February
Miss Mary L. Aiken, of Point Lawrence, Orcas island, is in the Harbor, the guest of Mrs. E. H. Sutherland.

April
Miss Mary Aiken of Point Lawrence, arrived in the Harbor Saturday evening and is the guest of Mrs. E. H. Sutherland. Miss Aiken is visiting her brothers at Whatcom.

May
Mrs. G. N. Culver, of Point Lawrence, who had been visiting her son and daughter here for a few days, returned home Tuesday.

June
Jay Aiken, fireman of the steamer Buckeye, is spending a few days visiting his aunts near Point Lawrence while the steamer is undergoing repairs.

August
Mrs. Alexander McLean, of Whatcom, and her little grandchild Miss Margaret Culver, returned home Tuesday evening on the Buckeye, after a two weeks visit with Mr. and Mrs. G. N. Culver and the Misses Aiken, at Alderbrook Farm, Point Lawrence.

Miss Blanch Simpson is visiting Mr. and Mrs. G. N. Culver and daughter at Alderbrook farm, Point Lawrence, Orcas island.

September
Miss Blanch Simpson returned home Friday from Point Lawrence, Orcas island, where she had been visiting friends for a few days.

October
Smallpox Scare Causes Great Excitement on Orcas Island: News reaches here that great consternation prevails at Orcas island over a possible case of smallpox.
notes: News items from The Islander newspaper mentioning Point Lawrence and Culver family
